Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 07:46PM LittleOldWineMaker wrote: HI MILIYA      Change doctors and change doctors NOW!!!!!  If you have to change doctors from now until Kingdon Come!  My sister (now 62) had a lump (that she could feel) went to her regular family doctor whose 'attitude' was 'oh let's just wait and see'.  At the YMCA running track she stopped the OB-GYN I go to (and she had worked for a few months) and explained the situation (there was NO family history involving women - breast and/or ovarian - NOTHING.  He told her to call his office and tell the 'receptionist that the 2 of them had talked and he was going to 'work her in', she went to him, he felt the mass (an although she was young, small breasted woman.  He called a wonderful surgeon (we've both been to him with 'lumps') that very afternoon; he felt it and although she was 'young' he did not think it was adviseable to take a 'wait and see' attitude; she was IN THE HOSPITAL THE VERY NEXT DAY, for a biopsy.  It had NOT spread outside the breast tissue (had not invaded any of the lympth nodes) but he laid out all the option (lumpectomy all the way to total mastectomy) and told her if he got in there and it was something cancerous - he would remove the breast, if that is what she chose.  She chose to be awaken, told the results, and surgery the next day.  He removed her breast...could not have immediate reconstruction because they had to put in some sort of skin stretcher, but it healed, and me and our other sister asked if we could see the 'mastectomy'.  Since it only involved breast tissue, she looked like a little 8-year-old girl, with no nipple, and a scar running at a 40 degree angle from her chest bone up to her arm pit.  HOWEVER, the plastic surgeon also offered Plan A - Plan ???.  She did not want to have an implant so she chose some sort of rotation flap surgery using her stomach muscles...I tried for weeks to discourage this because at the time (20+ years ago, it was a VERY new procedure) and the attorny I worked for had won a lawsuit where a woman had this surgery; the blood supply to the reconstructed breast, yes that 2 of them, got cut off, he did not seem to be concerned; but later she had to have MAJOR surgery for a double mastectomy and they had to take out all the muscle and graft skin...she was NEVER able to have any type of reconstruction.  Something very similiar happened to my sister...he ended up with about 23 hours of 'plastic surgery', each time he attempted to close the incision the blood supply was cut off.  She ended up with a small implant and a hole in her breast.  Again, sisters wondering if this might happen to them asked to see it, she relunctantly showed us.  Not a 'pretty' sight, but certainly not so gross as to make you want to 'throw up'.  The implant had started leaking (noticeably) so she went to the surgeon recommended by her GYN and he sent her to Plastic Surgeon...scheduled to 'repair, if possible' the breast involved.  In the meantime she had a yearly physical and a mass showed up in the other breast, so they moved the surgery up to this past Monday, depending on the biopsies of the mass and 1/2 the lymph nodes, they were able to do immediate reconstruction - using muscle from her back.  It was 'successful' according to her plastic surgeon.  I have implants which make my breast dense...all 3 lumps have been found by me, I've had biospies/lumpectomies on all three and clear tissue around all clean.  I told the surgeon that if it was cancerouos, I wanted to be awakened, told the diagnosis, and do a double mastectomy (husband in room - doctor sweet as an angel, said 'let's not start building and burning bridges before it becomes necessary, and then, we will talk again about your decision'.  My lumpectomy done the very same Monday.  It was, Thank you GOD - B9.  My Mother has ovarian cancer, but at 87 years old, we along with doctor decided that we should not put her through any treatment.  Given her age, she would probably succumb to a heart attack or stroke before the cancer - just draining abdomen to keep her comfortable.  Two times on the previous Monday my sister was called and told that Mother was 'unresponsive', but we all just pray she can continue to stay in the Assisted Living Facility and die peacefully in her sleep...she apparently has almost done so twice.  BUT AGAIN, CHANGE DOCTORS, DEMAND A SURGICAL BIOPSY...PITCH A TEE-TOTAL TEMPER TANTRUM...YOU HAVE MORE RIGHT TO DO SO THAT I...all I had to do was call GYN, tell him I felt lump about the size of a pea, that my husband had also felt it, and I was in his office immediately.  CHANGE, CHANGE, CHANGE, CHANGE, DOCTORS!!!!!
Posts.Title: Tired of being brused off milyla LittleOldWineMaker

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 07:25AM LittleOldWineMaker wrote: antpanda, You are in a lot of people's prayers.  My surgeon also said, 'don't start building bridges to burn, until we get to that point in the river.'
Posts.Title: Questions??? antpanda antpanda

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 07:47AM LittleOldWineMaker wrote: Mine, taken out Monday AM was B9.  Sister (now  62yrs - first mastectomy @ 39yrs.  Had restoration of a really "botched reconstruction - rotation flap from stomach - tried my best to talk her out of that particular surgery, PS made 'comment that she'd be getting a tummy tuck to boot' - wanted to monkey-jack slap him. I guess because I had been a legal sec'y and seen the results of a person having this type of surgery and how badly it turned out (it was a new procedure at that time), she just did not want implants.  But she got one anyway, started leaking - scheduled for surgery in Dec., but mammogram showed susp. area., biopsied, surgery moved up.  Had rotation flap this time from back) on both, she'd doing great...going to see her today.  Is that a little JACK RUSSLE Terrier puppy?  We have a JR and she is SO smart and does so many funny things.  Eats the cat's food.  Wish I had camera Friday, cat eating, she was sitting with her nose about 5" away from bowl.  Miss Kitty older and higher up on totem pole, so Shorty does not mess with her, even though she is 18 (cat) years old...so I'm sure she in REALLY old in human years.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 07:37AM LittleOldWineMaker wrote: I've had silicone implants since '81 (always did as plastic surgeon told me to - to keep from incapsulation - or husband do it - always manipulated to keep them soft; only once so bad I did so hard as to almost think I had burst it; but didn't.  Implants on top of chest muscle (in a 'natural pocket' behind breast tissue.  Makes breast tissue more dense - but I have found that this almost makes it easier to 'feel' a lump even if it doesn't show up on mammogram or a sonogram.  With my family history (oldest sister had BC @ 39yrs, and again at 62yrs), I check my breasts weekly, if not more often.  The 3 lumps I have found, I get my hubby to check, when he can put his finger right on it, I am calling my GYN.  This time, both GYN and surgeon very surprised I found it (small - would roll - and near nipple area; just about the same place and size as my 2d.  Just know that there are a whole lot of people praying for you, and most are benign.  Just do NOT ignore it.

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 11:22PM LittleOldWineMaker wrote: Hi, I too found a pea-sized lump (in left breast); I too have implants; because older sister had cancer @ 39-years went several years every 6 months for mammogram.  I've just had the 3 biopsy (today) and it was benign (Thank you God!).  Sister had double mastectomy & immediate reconstructon (actually 3d mastectomy - 1st reconstruction ('botched job in my opinion'); she ended up with implant which had started leaking; found cancer in other breast, moved up surgery.  I've had implants (silicone since early 80's and did exactly what plastic surgeon told me to do to keep them 'soft'.  I do have some encapsulation scarring, but I know where it is and how it feels.  Believes it makes breast tissue more dense (I had a mammogram which didn't 'really' show much to be concerned about in March - very small questional spot) and had sonogram (last week), which didn't show anything concrete, but GYN sent me to surgeon and because of family history, he would NOT take a 'wait and see' approach...had it out today - benign.  DO NOT 'WAIT & SEE', if you can 'feel' it, see about it immediately.  Demand to be sent to surgeon if necessary.  I had NO problem getting in as he has performed at least 2 (possibly 3 biopsies - all fatty benign lumps - but I am also rather diligent about self-breast exams, too, and all lumps have been found by me.  Personally I think the implants might make it easier to feel lumps; especially in tub/shower and soapy.  Check with my arms down, side, & over head (laying down and sitting up.  Make a pen mark at all places I can feel it, too.  This helps get the process of them 'looking/feeling' for it easier, too.  If sister had taken her 'family' doctor's 'wait & see' approach - she might not have lived to be 62.  She stopped OB-GYN I go to and that she had worked for, for a few months at the YMCA track...he worked her in the next day, sent to surgeon that afternoon, and was in hospital the next day.
Posts.Title: Questions??? antpanda antpanda

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 09:35AM LittleOldWineMaker wrote: When my oldest sister was 39, she felt a lump and went to her family physician...apparently he felt the lump, but told her to take a 'wait and see attitude' about it (she was too young to have cancer); however the next day she say the GYN that I go to and that she had worked for during the previous summer.  Stopped him, told him the story, and he said to call his office, tell the recp. that they had talked and that he was going to work her in.  She did, he did, he called a surgeon immediately - she went to see him and was IN the hospital the very next day.  Had mastectomy, had not spread past the breast tissue (when my middle sister and I asked if we could see it, she showed up - she looked like an 8yr old girl with no nipple and a scar running at a 40 degree angle from chest bone towards arm pit.  She did not have to have any chemo or other treatments.   She then went to a local PS who laid out every surgical procedure from plain old implants to a new procedure (at the time - a rotation flap from the stomach).  I tried talking her out of the rotation flap as being a legal sec'y had seen what problems this could cause for a thin woman with taunt skin.  However, when the PS piped in 'saying that she would also get a tummy tuck to boot', her mind was made up.  But 22+ hours of surgury later, each time the blood supply to the flap being cut off, he ended up sewing her up as far as he could, putting drains in, and he took a 'wait and see' attitude.  He also put in a small implant.  She was left with probably 2000 stitches, an implant she did not want, and a hole in her breast.  She is now 62, was scheduled to have the leaking implant removed and try a different rotation flap surgery,  taking muscle from her back.  Prior to surgery she had a mammogram and it showed an area that they decided to do a biopsy on.  It was cancerous, but had not spread from the breast tissue.  Her surgery was moved up (this past Monday; same day I had a lump biopsied - my 3d) and she is already home and doing good although she'll have to stay out of work a couple or 3 weeks.  This rotation flap surgery took muscle from her back.  PS not real sure how the 'repair' of the original reconstruction would do, but it apparently is doing fine.  If you feel a lump - go to your doctor.  My lump did not show up on the mammogram I had done in the middle of Mar of this year, it did not show up on the sonogram; but I could feel it, my husband - always my 'go behind' could feel it, the gyn could feel it and the surgeon also; think God it was B9.  Both the gyn and surgeon were quite surprised that I had found it...it was small, but after what happened to my sister (with no known family history) I might be somewhat a bit over-anxious, but I check my breast (at least once a week, in the tub, in the bed, arms down, to the side, and over my head.  If I feel something, I ask my hubby to see if he can feel it, if he does I am at my gyn immediately...you just can't 'wait and see' - you might just 'wait and see' yourself die from something that is really getting to the point that it can almost 80% benign.  If your doctor doesn't take you seriously -- change doctors!!!  Our 87yr old Mother has ovarian cancer, I am now thankful that when I had my hysterectomy that my gyn had no choice but to take my ovaries as well.  I told him I did not want anything left that would turn into cancer.  I'm 56, I had my surgery when I was 35, now because I had a case of lithium toxicity (I'm also Bipolar [manic/depressive]) I no longer take hormone replacement (my husband does not want me to because I had been on it 20 years 24/7/365 - but unfortunately I am having 'hot flashes'.  Hubby had kidney stones which is akin to having a baby...all I can say is I hope men have 'hot flashes, too!'  Many prayers for you and yours.  Worrying never changed anything...take a deep breath and tell yourself that the odds are in your favor...to the good!
